content: I have personal knowledge of (generally) what goes on at a Bilderberg conference. I was on the staff of someone who was invited to and attended one of them. It appears you don't know how groups operate at the international level. At their most basic, a body such as the UN or NATO has to operate on consensus - that is, everyone has to agree or the motion goes nowhere. This is a slow, painful process. And, after that, those delegates have to go back to their respective countries and convince their parliaments, businesses, etc., to implement whatever policy recommendations came from those meetings. That is an equally slow and painful process which has a success rate of, at best, about 50/50. So, take a resolution that the 26 NATO ambassadors agree on. Now, they go back to 26 countries, all of whom have their own political quirks. What are the odds of that agreement passing - and how long does that take?

content: Wow, could you people do some actual research of the ICC before blowing up about it? The TREATY for the ICC must be ratified by the state, i.e. the U.S. Senate, before it can come into effect. That is the language of the treaty. "Article 125 Signature, ratification, acceptance, approval or accession This Statute is subject to ratification, acceptance or approval by signatory States. Instruments of ratification, acceptance or approval shall be deposited with the Secretary-General of the United Nations." The court can not have jurisdiction until the treaty is entered into force. "Article 11 Jurisdiction ratione temporis 1. The Court has jurisdiction only with respect to crimes committed after the entry into force of this Statute. 2. If a State becomes a Party to this Statute after its entry into force, the Court may exercise its jurisdiction only with respect to crimes committed after the entry into force of this Statute for that State, unless that State has made a declaration under article 12, paragraph 3." "Article 126 Entry into force 1. This Statute shall enter into force on the first day of the month after the 60th day following the date of the deposit of the 60th instrument of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession with the Secretary-General of the United Nations. 2. For each State ratifying, accepting, approving or acceding to this Statute after the deposit of the 60th instrument of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession, the Statute shall enter into force on the first day of the month after the 60th day following the deposit by such State of its instrument of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession." *//untreaty.un.org/cod/icc/statute/romefra.htm NO OUTSIDE "HOT LINKS! The next time they will be deleted As for our constitution... "Article II - The Executive Branch Section 2 - Civilian Power over Military, Cabinet, Pardon Power, Appointments He shall have Power, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Senate, to make Treaties, provided two thirds of the Senators present concur;" Now, besides all of the safeguards for states, the ICC also has several provisions to ensure that states retain their sovereignty and also, that the ICC is not concerned with politics. Not only that, but it gives the states the right to try the individuals responsible for the crimes in their own courts first. The ICC is a court of last resort. It also only has jurisdicition over human rights violations and war crimes which the US and the international community recognizes. The US was instrumental in writing the Rome Statute and creating the ICC in the first place. And, the ICC is not an instrument of the UN, although the Security Council can refer cases to the court, such as the situation in Darfur. It is an international treaty. I am actually writing a paper about the possibility of the US becoming a member state of the ICC and its implications on our military, so I have done a lot of research. I am also going to the ICC at the Hague this summer to study the courts and continue my research. International law is my future career. This message has been edited. Last edited by: OldArmyLove, Tue 10 March 2009 07:19 AM
